title: 105_hr2838
content: The Act titled "Taxpayer Bill of Rights III" establishes that the Secretary bears the burden of proof in court proceedings regarding a taxpayer's tax liability. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to reflect this change. The burden of proof in court proceedings regarding a taxpayer's tax liability shifts to the Secretary, effective for examinations after the enactment of the Act. Taxpayers can rely on oral advice from the IRS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow taxpayers to request oral advice from the IRS, which must be provided in writing upon request. These amendments apply to advice given after 180 days from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 amends Section 6861 of the Internal Revenue Code to require affidavits from 2 IRS officers for assessments. The amendment applies to assessments made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5 allows taxpayers to make suggestions and complaints to the IRS without fear of retribution. SEC. 5 establishes an office within the IRS for taxpayer suggestions and complaints without retribution. Information provided will be confidential and cannot be used for audits. SEC. 6. MEDIATION OF TAX DISPUTES. The Secretary of the Treasury must establish a mediation service within the IRS to mediate disputes between taxpayers and the IRS regarding tax liability. SEC. 7. STRICT LIABILITY FOR ERRORS BY THE IRS. Amendments are made to sections regarding civil damages for failure to release liens and unauthorized collection actions. "SEC. 7433. Civil damages for unauthorized actions." If an IRS officer disregards tax laws, a taxpayer can sue the United States for damages in federal court. The damages awarded will be the lesser of $1,000,000 or the actual economic damages caused by the officer's actions, plus legal costs. The payment authority for claims under this section comes from funds appropriated under section 1304 of title 31, United States Code. Limitations include the possibility of reducing damages if administrative remedies are not exhausted, mitigating damages, and a specific period for bringing action. The plaintiff has a 2-year period to bring an action to enforce liability under this section. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 76. SEC. 9. PERSONAL LIABILITY OF INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE EMPLOYEES. This section amends the Internal Revenue Code to address personal liability of IRS employees. SEC. 7437 addresses the personal liability of Internal Revenue Service employees in cases where litigation costs are awarded to the prevailing party. The court may assess costs against IRS officers or employees if their actions were outside established IRS protocol. SEC. 7437 addresses the personal liability of IRS employees for litigation costs. SEC. 7438 provides cross-references. SEC. 10 prohibits IRS officers and employees from setting quotas for investigations or delinquent taxpayers. Effective Date: Amendments apply after enactment of this Act.
